title: Do Balance Disorders Go Away?
author: Medical Author Divya Jacob; Pharm D Medical Reviewer Pallavi Suyog Uttekar; MD
description: Generally, balance disorders last for a couple of days and the patient recovers slowly over 1 to 3 weeks. However, some patients may experience symptoms that can last for several months. For symptoms that don't go away with other treatments, the physician might prefer surgery.
cleaned_text: - [Do Balance Disorders Go Away?](#do_balance_disorders_go_away) - [What Is](#what_is_a_balance_disorder) [Causes](#what_causes_a_balance_disorder) - Do balance disorders go away? Generally, [balance disorders](https://www.medicinenet.com/balance_disorders_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) last for a couple of days and the patient recovers slowly over 1 to 3 weeks. However, some patients may experience symptoms that can last for several months. For symptoms that don't go away with other treatments, the physician might prefer surgery. What is a balance disorder? A balance disorder is a condition characterized by [dizziness](https://www.medicinenet.com/dizziness_dizzy/article.htm) and [vertigo](https://www.medicinenet.com/vertigo_overview/article.htm) while standing still or lying down. [Balance disorders](https://www.medicinenet.com/vertigo_balance_disorders_quiz/quiz.htm) can be caused due to certain medical conditions, injury, medications or an issue in the inner ear or the brain. The dizzy spell may vary from person to person. For some, [dizziness](https://www.medicinenet.com/dizziness/symptoms.htm) can be short-term whereas for oters dizziness may be an intense sensation of spinning that may last for a long time. A balance disorder can deeply affect daily activities and cause physical or emotional disturbances. What are the symptoms of a balance disorder? Symptoms of a balance disorder include - Dizziness or [vertigo](https://www.medicinenet.com/balance_disorders_pictures_slideshow/article.htm) - Swaying [Confusion](https://www.medicinenet.com/confusion/symptoms.htm)or disorientation [Blurred vision](https://www.medicinenet.com/blurred_vision/symptoms.htm) [Lightheadedness](https://www.medicinenet.com/dizziness_dizzy/article.htm), faintness or a floating sensation - Staggering while [walking](https://www.medicinenet.com/walking/article.htm) - Feeling as if you are going to fall Other symptoms may include [Nausea](https://www.medicinenet.com/nausea_and_vomiting/article.htm)and [vomiting](https://www.medicinenet.com/nausea_and_vomiting/article.htm) [Diarrhea](https://www.medicinenet.com/diarrhea/article.htm) - Changes in [heart](https://www.medicinenet.com/heart_how_the_heart_works/article.htm)rate Fear [Anxiety](https://www.medicinenet.com/anxiety/article.htm) - Panic [Fatigue](https://www.medicinenet.com/fatigue/article.htm) [Depression](https://www.medicinenet.com/depression/article.htm) What causes a balance disorder? A balance disorder can be caused due to various factors, including - Viral or [bacterial infections](https://www.medicinenet.com/bacterial_infections_101_pictures_slideshow/article.htm)in the ear [Head injury](https://www.medicinenet.com/head_injury/article.htm) - Cervical spondylosis - Blood circulation disorders - Certain medications - Problems in the visual, nervous, circulatory and skeletal system [Low blood pressure](https://www.medicinenet.com/low_blood_pressure/article.htm) [Arthritis](https://www.medicinenet.com/arthritis/article.htm) - Eye muscle imbalance However, many balance disorders do not have an exact cause. What are the different types of balance disorders? The different types of balance disorders include - Benign paroxysmal positional [vertigo](https://www.medicinenet.com/vertigo_balance_disorders_quiz/quiz.htm)(BPPV) or positional [vertigo](https://www.medicinenet.com/vertigo/symptoms.htm): This is a short, powerful episode of vertigo that occurs due to a specific change in the position of the head. [Labyrinthitis](https://www.medicinenet.com/labyrinthitis_inner_ear_inflammation/article.htm): Infection or inflammation in the inner ear causes dizziness and loss of balance. - Meniere's disease: Fluid change in the inner ear tube. [Vestibular neuronitis](https://www.medicinenet.com/balance_disorders_pictures_slideshow/article.htm): Viral infection may cause inflammation of the [vestibular](https://www.medicinenet.com/balance_disorders_pictures_slideshow/article.htm)nerve. - Perilymph fistula: This is the leakage of inner ear fluid into the middle ear. It can occur after a [head injury](https://www.medicinenet.com/head_injury_symptoms_and_signs/symptoms.htm)due to drastic changes in atmospheric pressure (such as when scuba diving) or after ear surgery. - Mal de debarquement syndrome (MdDs): This is characterized by continuous bobbing feeling after travelling on a ship. How is a balance disorder diagnosed? The physician may review your medical history as well as conduct a physical and neurological examination. To check problems in the balance function in the inner ear, the doctor might recommend the following tests [Hearing](https://www.medicinenet.com/deafness/article.htm)tests: Difficulties in hearing will be associated with balance problems. - Posturography test: It indicates the part of the balance system that is used more. - Electronystagmography and videonystagmography: These tests record your involuntary eye movements. - Rotary chair test: Eye movements are analyzed while sitting in a computer-controlled chair. - Dix-Hallpike maneuver: Rotation of the head in different motions while observing the eye movements can help to identify a false sense of motion or spinning. - Vestibular-evoked myogenic potentials test: Sensor pads are attached to the neck and forehead to measure the muscle contractions in reaction to sounds. - Imaging tests like [MRI](https://www.medicinenet.com/mri_scan/article.htm)and [CT scans](https://www.medicinenet.com/cat_scan/article.htm) - Blood pressure and heart rate tests: Blood pressure measured while sitting and then standing for 2 to 3 minutes may help to determine if there is a significant fall in blood pressure. How is a balance disorder treated? Treatment depends on the cause of balance disorder, which may include - Treat any underlying infections using antibiotics or antifungals. - Make changes in [diet](https://www.medicinenet.com/diet_plans_and_programs/article.htm)and activity, such as quitting [smoking](https://www.medicinenet.com/smoking_and_quitting_smoking/article.htm) - Try canalith repositioning maneuvers that are a specialized series of head and chest movements. These may remove small calcium deposits in the inner ear causing giddiness. - Get surgery when medications and other therapies do not fix the problem. - Receive rehabilitation, such as balance retraining therapy. What Can Trigger Vertigo?Vertigo is the sensation of spinning or rocking, even when someone is at rest. Vertigo may be caused by a problem in the brain or spinal cord or a problem within in the inner ear. Head injuries, certain medications, and female gender are associated with a higher risk of vertigo. Medical history, a physical exam, and sometimes an MRI or CT scan are required to diagnose vertigo. The treatment of vertigo may include medication, special exercises to reposition loose crystals in the inner ear, or exercises designed to help the patient re-establish a sense of equilibrium. Controlling risk factors for stroke (blood pressure, weight, cholesterol, and blood glucose) may decrease the risk of developing vertigo. What Causes Vertigo?Vertigo is a symptom that is characterized by a false sensation of spinning of the head or of surrounding objects when they are not. Patients feel giddy or dizzy and lose balance.
